case_vignette: A 3000-g (6.6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has had no prenatal care. Immunization records are not available. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. There are several bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass his auditory screening tests.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

Well, I'm not sure what I'm supposed to say, since I'm just a newborn, but they told me there's a constant heart murmur, some blue spots on my skin that don't go away when you press them, my eyes have something cloudy in them, and I didn't pass the hearing tests they gave me.

Final Diagnosis: Congenital Heart Disease with Cyánosis, Jaundice, and Hearing Impairment (CCHD with Cyanosis, Jaundice, and Hearing Impairment) or Alagille Syndrome. Which one fits your condition? (Additional tests may be needed for confirmation.)

Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is a congenital heart defect with cyanosis (blue discoloration of the skin) and hearing impairment. This condition is often referred to as a "blue baby syndrome" and requires further evaluation by a pediatric cardiologist and an audiologist. The specific diagnosis will depend on the results of various tests, including echocardiography, hearing tests, and blood tests. It is important to note that this diagnosis should be confirmed by a healthcare professional.
